change.li: $Log: encyclopedia.xml,v $ Revision 1.28 2006/03/27 14:02:23 gcrane more refinements Revision 1.27 2006/03/26 04:13:20 gcrane more fixes Revision 1.26 2006/03/25 19:26:47 gcrane more fixes Revision 1.25 2006/03/25 16:38:06 gcrane Did a lot of work to clean up the base headers for subentries. These should more often now only include global descriptions, e.g, PERSON, son of A stays, but PERSON, fought at Troy goes. --> "Fought at Troy" can be one of many events and is not a global identifier Revision 1.24 2006/03/20 19:15:42 gcrane cleaned up the formatting Revision 1.23 2006/03/20 14:15:22 gcrane small changes Revision 1.20 2006/03/18 15:34:36 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.19 2006/03/18 01:14:23 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.18 2006/03/17 23:55:18 gaweaver small fixes Revision 1.17 2006/03/17 21:56:39 gaweaver Calliopi From Antiphon until Chilon Revision 1.16 2006/03/17 15:39:04 gaweaver no message Revision 1.15 2006/03/10 00:01:20 gaweaver changes made by GRC while over the atlantic Revision 1.14 2006/03/05 03:47:42 gcrane base file Revision 1.13 2006/03/04 13:13:03 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.12 2006/03/03 18:21:05 gaweaver Agenor (10) Revision 1.11 2006/02/15 16:24:46 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.10 2006/02/13 21:52:23 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.9 2006/02/13 01:57:42 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.8 2006/02/12 23:12:05 gcrane small fixes Revision 1.7 2006/02/12 15:30:08 gcrane major structural update: the descriptive info has now been moved up into the headers and id's added to div1 type="entry" Revision 1.6 2006/02/12 13:23:59 gcrane moved descriptions up into the header: the goal is to make the header more informative and thus to facilitate the mechanics of aligning entries in this list with those in Smith's etc Revision 1.5 2006/02/11 19:49:21 gcrane more small fixes to make the coding consistent Revision 1.4 2006/02/11 18:50:04 gcrane working towards moving identifiers for all entities up into the subentry HEAD Revision 1.3 2006/02/10 22:43:14 gcrane changed the structure so that every entry has a subentry -- this simplifies the structure (i hope) Revision 1.2 2005/08/18 13:53:45 packel item tags... Revision 1.1 2005/07/25 14:32:52 packel Converted to XML Revision 1.34 2003/07/01 22:16:05 yorkc Updated texts to TEI P4 and Perseus P4 extensions; minor cleanup (esp. character encodings and typos.) Revision 1.31 2000/03/15 15:12:45 amahoney make homonyms sub-entries Revision 1.30 2000/03/14 18:11:05 amahoney several more random issues, but the Apollodorus refs really are right now Revision 1.27 2000/03/04 20:34:25 dasmith Added separate funder entity to TEI header. div3.p: The molding which is slanted upward to follow the slope of the triangular pediment.

Description: In the earliest Doric architecture the raking cornice of the pediment usually differed in height and moldings from the horizontal cornice. In the Ionic order, the raking cornice was usually identical in form with the horizontal cornice. In the Ionic order it frequently is elaborated with ancillary moldings as well as brackets, modillions, and dentils.

div3.p: Refers to the series of adjustments in building design made by Classical Greek architects to overcome visual peculiarities.

Description: The Parthenon is often put forth as the culmination or epitome of refinements. The adjustments were made to compensate for what the architects thought a viewer would perceive when looking at a building of such monumental size.

ul.li: of Olympic victors: kept by Eleans: Paus. 3.21.1, Paus. 5.21.9, Paus. 6.2.3, Paus. 6.13.10, Paus. 10.36.9, cf.Paus. 6.6.3, Paus. 6.8.1

div3.p: A narrow projecting band located beneath the taenia onto which are attached the guttae.
Description: Located just under each triglyph, the regulae should not be confused with the mutules, which also carry guttae, that appear in the Doric cornice.
Generally triangular in shape (thus the name), a space left above the lintel to relieve the pressure being exerted, by the above layers, on the lentil, a feature unique to megalithic architecture.

div3.p: A drinking vessel shaped like a horn and usually in the form of an animal's head.

Term: From literary and artistic evidence, we know that the terms rhyton, rheon and protome were all used to identify drinking horns in the form of animal heads, during and following the fourth century B.C.
